opened_prs.title: feat: don't include hashes of preimages in execution witness
opened_prs.body:
Switch execution witness to return vectors instead of hashes. There's no reason to include the hash of the preimage in the response, potentially allowing callers to trust the EL client unnecessarily. No other clients implement this RPC and the only usage currently is in optimism and kona. I'll update these usages once this is merged.

Request from geth team here: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/30613#issuecomment-2531732780

Once this is complete, I can start implementing `debug_executePayload` method in geth and execution-apis.

Edit: this is blocked by https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/pull/14503

opened_prs.title: feat/subscribe-best-payloads
opened_prs.body:
Hello guys,

I have a use case where I need to resolve a payload when a realtime condition on the best payload is met
To achieve this, I need realtime notifications on the best payloads.

To support this feature, I extended the `PayloadBuilderHandle` with 
```rust
    pub async fn subscribe_best_payload(
        &self,
        id: PayloadId,
    )  -> Stream..
```

If you are interested I can provide a cleaner solution.

opened_prs.title: [wip] refactor: `BlockExecutionStrategy` API
opened_prs.body:
Changes in this PR:
- `SystemCaller` is refactored so that all its methods take an `Evm` as input. That way we can avoid having `EvmConfig` generic on it, and encourage callers to reuse `Evm`s for both transaction and system calls execution, avoiding additional allocations
- `BlockExecutionStrategy` is refactored, changes include:
    - It is made disposable, i.e strategy lifespan corresponds to a single executed block
    - a single strategy creates and reuses single Evm for entire block execution
    - strategy API now does not contain any inputs besides transactions

This PR unlocks the following improvements:
1. None of `BlockExecutionStrategy` methods now require providing a full block as input making it suitable for re-use in block building. We still need an entire block to initialize the strategy though, and this can be changed by introducing a helper intermiddiate configuration struct for it. This struct would be implementation-specific and can be abstracted away like we do with `EvmEnv`
2. Strategy having ownership over an EVM allows us to introduce `Strategy::execute_transaction` API without perf penalty for re-initializing EVM on every call. The benefit of this API is that it would make strategy API suitable for payload building when a set of transactions is determined dynamically and can't be passed as `Vec<Tx>` into `execute_transactions`

opened_prs.title: [wip] feat: `HeaderBuilder`
opened_prs.body:
RIght now the only type which knows how to construct a header is `PayloadBuilder`. This is unconvinient because we have peripheral usecases requiring constructing a block which ideally should not be embedded into PayloadBuilder logic. Examples of such usecases are complex RPC functionality (`eth_simulateV1`, pending block building), `debug.reorg` flags.

This PR experiments with a simpler trait providing access to header building logic. The idea is that caller can construct payload attributes and block body, delegate the execution to block executor, and then simply invoke `HeaderBuilder` to finish block building.

The cache handling logic has been optimized to directly reference the cache during precompile setup.

Additionally, I’ve ensured that struct and type aliases are used consistently across the code, improving readability and maintainability. 

This should address the previously observed issues with cache management and make the configuration more efficient.

Trying to launch a new archival node using [ghcr.io/paradigmxyz/reth-reproducible:v1.2.0](https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/pkgs/container/reth-reproducible), but it crashes soon after launch with SIGSEGV

labels.name: C-bug
labels.description: An unexpected or incorrect behavior

labels.name: A-db
labels.description: Related to the database

labels.name: A-op-reth
labels.description: Related to Optimism and op-reth

opened_issues.body: ### Describe the bug We have multiple nodes, and it never reaches the tip. It has enough memory & cpu, we're using ssds. Looks like every time it reaches the tip, id does the unwind and repeats over and over. ```` 2025-02-15T13:00:34.535453Z INFO Finished stage pipeline_stages=4/12 stage=Execution checkpoint=26416240 target=26416240 stage_progress=100.00% 2025-02-15T13:00:53.709434Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:01:18.709214Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:01:43.709690Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:02:08.708949Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:02:33.709765Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:02:58.708836Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:03:23.709553Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:03:48.708931Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:04:13.709501Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:04:38.709828Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:05:03.709388Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:05:28.708990Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:05:53.709537Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 latest_block=26404535 2025-02-15T13:06:13.617441Z INFO Stage is always skipped 2025-02-15T13:06:13.617460Z INFO Preparing stage pipeline_stages=5/12 stage=MerkleUnwind checkpoint=26404535 target=26416240 2025-02-15T13:06:13.617476Z INFO Executing stage pipeline_stages=5/12 stage=MerkleUnwind checkpoint=26404535 target=26416240 2025-02-15T13:06:13.617501Z INFO Finished stage pipeline_stages=5/12 stage=MerkleUnwind checkpoint=26416240 target=26416240 2025-02-15T13:06:13.622258Z INFO Preparing stage pipeline_stages=6/12 stage=AccountHashing checkpoint=26404535 target=26416240 2025-02-15T13:06:13.622270Z INFO Executing stage pipeline_stages=6/12 stage=AccountHashing checkpoint=26404535 target=26416240 2025-02-15T13:06:18.709399Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 stage=AccountHashing checkpoint=26404535 target=26416240 2025-02-15T13:06:43.709397Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 stage=AccountHashing checkpoint=26404535 target=26416240 2025-02-15T13:07:08.709233Z INFO Status connected_peers=17 stage=AccountHashing checkpoint=26404535 target=26416240 ```` `eth_syncing` shows ```` { "jsonrpc": "2.0", "id": 1, "result": { "startingBlock": "0x192286b", "currentBlock": "0x192f329", "highestBlock": "0x192f329", "warpChunksAmount": null, "warpChunksProcessed": null, "stages": [ { "name": "AccountHashing", "block": "0x1932471" }, { "name": "Bodies", "block": "0x1932471" }, { "name": "Execution", "block": "0x1932471" }, { "name": "Finish", "block": "0x192f329" }, { "name": "Headers", "block": "0x1932471" }, { "name": "IndexAccountHistory", "block": "0x192f329" }, { "name": "IndexStorageHistory", "block": "0x192f329" }, { "name": "MerkleExecute", "block": "0x192f329" }, { "name": "MerkleUnwind", "block": "0x1932471" }, { "name": "Prune", "block": "0x189164b" }, { "name": "PruneSenderRecovery", "block": "0x189164b" }, { "name": "SenderRecovery", "block": "0x1932471" }, { "name": "StorageHashing", "block": "0x192f329" }, { "name": "TransactionLookup", "block": "0x192f329" } ] } } ```` Charts from metrics are pretty weird Thanks ### Steps to reproduce we're on `reth 1.2.0` and `op-node 1.11.0`, started from archive snapshot op-reth started with ```` "node", "-vvv", "--chain=base", "--rollup.sequencer-http=https://mainnet-sequencer.base.org", "--rollup.disable-tx-pool-gossip", "--config=/data/reth.toml", "--datadir=/data", "--http", "--http.addr=0.0.0.0", "--http.port=18565", "--http.corsdomain=*", "--http.api=debug,eth,net,trace,txpool,web3,rpc,reth,ots,flashbots", "--authrpc.addr=0.0.0.0", "--authrpc.port=18561", "--authrpc.jwtsecret=/data/jwt.txt", "--rollup.discovery.v4", "--engine.persistence-threshold", "10", "--engine.memory-block-buffer-target", "10", "--port", "30302", "--discovery.port", "30302", "--enable-discv5-discovery", "--discovery.v5.addr", "0.0.0.0", "--discovery.v5.port", "30306", "--metrics", ":9001" ```` was experimenting with engine.persistence-threshold and buffer-target, no diff we're on execution-layer syncmode in op-node. ### Node logs ```text ``` ### Platform(s) Linux (x86) ### Container Type Docker ### What version/commit are you on? ```` reth-optimism-cli Version: 1.2.0 Commit SHA: 1e0b0d897b372226b3f0ebf911b5176132c322d7 Build Timestamp: 2025-02-12T17:18:11.840476772Z Build Features: asm_keccak,jemalloc,optimism Build Profile: maxperf ```` ### What database version are you on? 2 ### Which chain / network are you on? base mainnet ### What type of node are you running? Archive (default) ### What prune config do you use, if any? part from reth.toml ```` [stages.prune] commit_threshold = 1000000 [stages.account_hashing] clean_threshold = 500000 commit_threshold = 100000 [stages.storage_hashing] clean_threshold = 500000 commit_threshold = 100000 [stages.merkle] clean_threshold = 5000 [stages.transaction_lookup] chunk_size = 5000000 [stages.index_account_history] commit_threshold = 100000 [stages.index_storage_history] commit_threshold = 100000 [stages.etl] file_size = 524288000 [prune] block_interval = 5 [prune.segments.receipts_log_filter] ```` ### If you've built Reth from source, provide the full command you used _No response_ ### Code of Conduct - [x] I agree to follow the Code of Conduct

opened_issues.title: Allow extending engine capabilities

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: D-good-first-issue
labels.description: Nice and easy! A great choice to get started

labels.name: A-rpc
labels.description: Related to the RPC implementation

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

currently this only stores an immutable list with a fixed set of features

https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/16c3c5b733702f31daa4bf4e2c688ce37ccd5b58/crates/rpc/rpc-engine-api/src/capabilities.rs#L27-L27


we need this to be configurable for op and also customizable in case the engine API is extended with additional functions, for example for experimental caps.

## TODO
* add constructor
* add insert + remove

_No response_

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the bug

After upgrading reth I had a regression test failing that uses historical state. E.g. the balance of the zero-address differs for block `20_000_000` (and others) between different versions of reth.

I tested the zero-address balance on separate instances of reth `v1.1.3`, `v1.1.5`, and `v1.2.0`, all returning different results. Additionally I included the results of two public archive rpc providers. While I have no idea if they are using reth, I find it interesting, that they return different results too.

```
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"eth_getBalance","params":["0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000","0x1312d00"],"id":1}
```

Node            | Balance
----------------|-----------------------
reth v1.1.3     | `0x2d901dc3cccc22a53cf`
reth v1.1.5     | `0x2d8e0cd974dd248da9e`
reth v1.2.0     | `0x2d8de1ecb276cededc9`
llama           | `0x2d579658aeefe65adbc`
ankr            | `0x2d48a339d420097f171`


### Steps to reproduce

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Define block number
BLOCK_NUMBER=$(printf "0x%x" 20000000)

# Define endpoints with labels using an associative array
declare -A endpoints=(
    [reth_v1_2_0]="http://localhost:8545"
    # [reth_v1_1_5]=""
    # [reth_v1_1_3]=""
    [ankr]="https://rpc.ankr.com/eth"
    [llama]="https://eth.llamarpc.com"
)

# Print table header
printf "%-15s | %s\n" "Node" "Balance"
printf '%.0s-' {1..40}
echo

# Iterate over endpoints and fetch balance
for label in "${!endpoints[@]}"; do
    url="${endpoints[$label]}"
    response=$(curl -s "$url" --no-keepalive \
      -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
      -d '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"eth_getBalance","params":["0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000","'"$BLOCK_NUMBER"'"],"id":1}' | jq -r .result)

    printf "%-15s | %s\n" "$label" "$response"
done
```


opened_issues.title: `PayloadServiceBuilder` should not require `PayloadBuilder`

labels.name: A-sdk
labels.description: Related to reth's use as a library

opened_issues.body:
Unfortunately, #14276 makes life hard for our block pipeline that implements our own `PayloadJob` and `PayloadJobGenerator` that don't use   `PayloadBuilder`. 

I'd say that `PayloadBuilder` is an implementation detail of `BasicPayloadJob` and `BasicPayloadJobGenerator` and should not be leaked to `PayloadServiceBuilder`. `try_build` takes in `reth_basic_payload_builder::BuildArguments` (emphasized on `_basic_`) that may not fit custom payload builders like for our multi-threaded builder. And the `PayloadBuilderService` everyone uses doesn't interface directly with a `PayloadBuilder`.

#14276 as is forces advanced payload services to check in an unused `PayloadBuilder` with unreachable `try_build` and `build_empty_payload` methods, which is very unfortunate...

opened_issues.title: Fetch partial proofs for State Root Task

labels.name: S-needs-design
labels.description: This issue requires design work to think about how it would best be accomplished

labels.name: C-perf
labels.description: A change motivated by improving speed, memory usage or disk footprint

labels.name: A-engine
labels.description: Related to the engine implementation

labels.name: A-trie
labels.description: Related to Merkle Patricia Trie implementation

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

Currently, every time we fetch new proofs for the State Root Task, we call into `ParallelProof` with a list of targets, and it returns a list of trie nodes for these targets, starting from the root node.

The problem with this approach is that we fetch root node and many other nodes below it, that were already fetched before, over and over again. A nice optimization here would be to fetch only those nodes that weren't fetch in this run of the State Root Task. This will potentially save on I/O, because we need to go to disk for less nodes.

### Additional context

_No response_

opened_issues.title: docs: changelog for updates to SDK API

labels.name: C-docs
labels.description: An addition or correction to our documentation

labels.name: S-feedback-wanted
labels.description: This issue/PR is looking for feedback

opened_issues.body:
### Describe the change

Scroll is currently maintaining a fork of Reth with very minor changes, focusing on using [Reth as an SDK](https://github.com/scroll-tech/reth/tree/scroll/crates/scroll). We perform a merge from upstream once a week, and the major part of the work is centered around fixing changes to public traits, on which custom implementations are required when using the SDK pattern (e.g. [Evm](https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/37adaf2d2e246a05326b64d98d219d5a042d902f/crates/evm/src/lib.rs#L53), [ConfigureEvm](https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/37adaf2d2e246a05326b64d98d219d5a042d902f/crates/evm/src/lib.rs#L99), [Trace](https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/37adaf2d2e246a05326b64d98d219d5a042d902f/crates/rpc/rpc-eth-api/src/helpers/trace.rs#L28)).

Changes to these traits, as minimal as they are, can cause a compilation issue due to unsatisfied trait bounds which can sometimes be painful to track. This was recently the case for us with the `Trace` trait, on which a bound for `EthApiTypes::Error:  FromEvmError<Self::Evm>` was [added](https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/commit/98a021ee7d44f5969d99d64c45c540f3af2a58a7#diff-42d5da22f2650317764bf0076f5e694fe7f0f15adfb981a3141ac13bcfd21f97R35). Not adding the bound to the implementation caused the compiler to fail with some painful error (`the trait bound <ScrollEthApi<N> as EthApiTypes>::Error: From<<<ScrollEthApi<N> as RpcNodeCore>::Evm as ConfigureEvm>::EvmError<ProviderError>> is not satisfied`).

As these API changes start to accumulate over multiple commits and without any guiding line on the changes, we are forced to try compiling the codebase and follow the compilation errors as they arrive. We believe we could benefit from a changelog which would sum up changes done to these traits but any other solution that helps us reduce the time spent on fixing changes to the SDK is also very welcome.

### Additional context

_No response_

closed_prs.title: feat: use `SealedHeader` in `ChainSpec`
closed_prs.body:
Closes https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/issues/14469
Closes https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/issues/14355
Supersedes https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/pull/14441

Requires header to always be provided when setting up a chainspec.

This unblocks custom chain-dependant logic for `Genesis` -> `Header` conversion required for e.g Isthmus, and allows to make chainspec generic over header.

We still need `make_genesis_header` as it's useful for basic conversion, not sure if it makes more sense to put it somewhere else vs just a free function?

closed_prs.title: feat: add Unichain mainnet support
closed_prs.body:
I have seen #14240 regarding automating the import of L2 chains, but until it is ready, I thought of adding the Unichain mainnet directly to reth. The sync is working, and everything looks fine. Hope it is ok to add more OP Superchain's here.

**Remarks:**  
- The Unichain JSON is from [here](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/blob/main/superchain/extra/genesis/sepolia/unichain.json.zst). I compacted it like the other files but added it only once. It seems there are unused duplicates, e.g., `base.json`.  
- I did not copy/paste the ForkId tests from [here](https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/b7193423/crates/optimism/chainspec/src/lib.rs#L445), as I could not find a good resource to support the ForkIds used, and #8012 is still open. Maybe it is possible to have more verbose variables. Anyway, Unichain only has Cancun and Holocene.  
- `alloy_chains` currently has no `Chain::unichain_mainnet()`, so I used `Chain::from_named(NamedChain::Unichain)` instead. I can create a PR for that in `alloy_chains`.  
- When syncing, I could not discover any nodes with `op-node`, so I used the bootstrap nodes from [here](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/blob/optimism/params/bootnodes.go#L85) from Uniswap Labs.

closed_prs.title: feat(reth-bench): send-payload CLI
closed_prs.body:
Pulled out of https://github.com/Rjected/execution-payload-builder, migrated to Alloy, and cleaned up.

Still not perfect Alloy migration-wise (had to create a wrapper enum with delegated methods), but https://github.com/alloy-rs/op-alloy/pull/427 and other improvements should fix that in the future.

```console
$ cast block 21837989 -r https://reth-ethereum.ithaca.xyz/rpc --full --json | reth-bench send-payload --rpc-url localhost:5000 --jwt-secret /mnt/nvme/reth/mainnet/jwt.hex
{"status":"VALID","latestValidHash":"0x6ab2f864c1fedab183e1ea3470e97c0f5b0ef6d4fe82f501fba337a0ecb66f5d","validationError":null}
```

labels.description: Related to Optimism and op-reth

closed_issues.body:
Closes https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/issues/14469
Closes https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/issues/14355
Supersedes https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/pull/14441

Requires header to always be provided when setting up a chainspec.

This unblocks custom chain-dependant logic for `Genesis` -> `Header` conversion required for e.g Isthmus, and allows to make chainspec generic over header.

We still need `make_genesis_header` as it's useful for basic conversion, not sure if it makes more sense to put it somewhere else vs just a free function?

closed_issues.title: replace Into<Self> bound with standalone function

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: D-good-first-issue
labels.description: Nice and easy! A great choice to get started

labels.name: A-sdk
labels.description: Related to reth's use as a library

closed_issues.body:
### Describe the feature

due to Into<Self> we can't use `&Self` as the compat type 

https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/16c3c5b733702f31daa4bf4e2c688ce37ccd5b58/crates/primitives-traits/src/serde_bincode_compat.rs#L15-L21

similar limitation why we added `as_repr`, now we need to introduce

```rust
from_repr
```

and replace the Into bound with that, this way we can use &Self as the compat

## TODO
* replace Into<Self> with `from_repr(Self::BincodeRepr<'_>) -> Self` 
* update all impls

### Additional context

_No response_

closed_issues.title: fix(mev): Fix issues in mev_simBundle.
closed_issues.body:
This fixes a couple issues with `mev_simBundle`:

- It was defaulting to `"pending"` instead of `"latest"`
- If incorrectly converting tags to block numbers, leading to a panic.
- It was mapping all errors to `bundle timeout` 

We're still doing more exhaustive testing on Holesky so might have some follow-on PRs but this one passes basic sanity checks of simulating a simple bundle.

wartime_milady_ceo_summary: - **Dependency Updates and Fixes**: The recent PR #14522 involved an automated weekly `cargo update`, which updated 38 packages to their latest compatible versions. Key updates included packages like `alloy-chains`, `alloy-consensus-any`, and `blst`, among others. Additionally, PR #14519 fixed an issue related to incorrect table types on drop, ensuring correct type usage without affecting functionality.

- **Enhancements and Features**: PR #14514 introduced the use of `SealedHeader` in `ChainSpec`, which requires a header to be provided when setting up a chainspec, facilitating custom chain-dependent logic. Moreover, PR #14513 re-exported `reth-trie` with the trie feature,
